results.title: A Chance to travel
results.creator_credit: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When George Snowden joined the Australian army, he was given the opportunity to tour Australia. Despite being given the chance to travel across the country, Snowden ended up suffering from a knee injury and was happy to return home after seeing most of the country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: First Sino-Japanese War = 甲午风云
results.creator_credit: Nong Lin, Changchun Film Company and Yi Xi
results.brief_description:
The film deals specifically with two naval conflicts at Fengdao Island and the Yellow Sea, during the 1894 Sino-Japanese War. The Chinese navy encounters the Japanese on the sea and, because of secret deals and the cowardice of the Chinese officers, refuses to engage them. The ordinary seamen aboard the Chinese vessel are outraged and eventually mutiny to fight the Japanese. The mutineers later join another vessel which is captained by a die-hard patriot and fighting man who leads them to a minor victory. The film ends on this positive note that the Chinese people have always been loyal and willing to fight, and its military losses were due largely to the corrupt and weak upper classes.
The film, which can be considered as war propaganda, avoids the Chinese navy’s humiliating military defeat by blaming the corrupt officials and ranking officers, who lacked the courage and will to sacrifice for their country. These heroic qualities are instead held by those low-ranking seamen, who have been disenfranchised by China’s then feudal system. The film invokes strong pejorative cultural and moral stereotypes against the Japanese, who all dress in extravagant Western clothes and hatch vile diplomatic schemes to defraud the Chinese people from a clean and honest fight. The film should in no way be taken as a historically reliable account of the events that unfolded during the Sino-Japanese War. However, it is a keen insight into the historical revisionism and aspirations of the Chinese Communist Government which dealt a critical hand in producing the film.
(Awards: 1983 - Winner of Portugal’s 12th Festroia International Film Festival’s Jury Prize.)
(James Donald, 3 star rating, 2010).

results.title: An interview with Patrick Bourke
results.brief_description: Patrick Bourke was 16 when he grew onions with his father. Wanting to get out of this, he decided to join the navy. After convincing his father, he started work on his first ship H.M.A.S Adele, sighting subs and signalling wherever he was. Patrick retells some of his tales out at sea.

results.title: John Miles: drafted Vietnam
results.brief_description: John Miles recalls the 29th of September 1965 as the date that he commenced his National Service. While he was away, the political climate changed dramatically in Australia. Miles remembers his experience of the Vietnam War and his struggles once home in Australia. Miles’ treatment on return to Australia initially made left him feeling bitter, but a trip back to Vietnam was crucial to his personal transformation and healing.

results.title: An interview with Cyril Sayles
results.brief_description: At the age of 16, Cyril Sayles, not wanting to continue his manual labour in the mines, decided to join the army. Having lied about his age, he had a special made uniform and was off to fight the Germans in World War II. Cyril humorously shares his story of strength and courage, through his battle and imprisonment during the war.

results.title: Interview with Ben Whitham
results.brief_description: In war, you are discouraged from keeping records or taking photographs. However, soldiers broke those rules in order to help remember. Born on a small soldier’s settlement farm, Ben Witham grew up hearing stories about the war. Having a father who served in Gallipoli, to his own service in World War II, Witham recalls the camaraderie and the lighter side of war. He emphasises the bonds of fellow servicemen and the celebration of this during commemorations for ANZACs.

results.title: Over in 3 weeks
results.creator_credit: Tom Ross, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Once Tom Ross and his fellow soldiers settled in Singapore, the bombing started. In three weeks, they were captured and sent to Changi, where Ross was a prisoner of war for three and a half years. Despite the abject conditions, Ross managed to survive through sheer determination and will to live.

results.title: Join the navy and see the world they say
results.creator_credit: Ron Baguley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Inspired by his childhood hero, ‘Uncle Jack’, Ron Baguley enlisted in the Navy at the ripe age of 16. “Join the Navy and see the world they say!” In 1952, Ron was plucked from his job as a carpenter and thrown into a life at sea, serving initially in the Korean Conflict. Ron tracks his incredibly journey from a young recruit to a senior warrant officer.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ron Baguley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: My brother's birthday
results.creator_credit: Max Hammond, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In Syria, on the way to Beirut, Max Hammond’s thoughts turned to his family. One of seven children, Hammond and his three brothers served together in World War II. He recounts a close call that occurred on his brother’s birthday and reflects on how lucky he and his brothers are.

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
